title: WCAS AF_AM_ST 480-0-20 Graduate Topics in African American Studies

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This seminar illuminates decolonial horizons - visions of, ideas about, and plans for social existence that escape the stranglehold of mono-epistemic and/or Eurocentric (white, [settler]colonial, heteropatriarchal, imperialist, capitalist, ?) articulations of the political, progress, and reform (the cartography of power in this modern and global political economy). We'll begin with a brief genealogy of western modernity and of modern nation states like the U.S., an effort to excavate their racial/colonial architecture and thus expose their systemic and routine affects and effects (slavery, genocide, hyper-carceralism, alienation, and etc). Thereafter, most of our time will be spent mapping and debating decolonial theories and methods, focusing on; native resistance, fugitivity or maroonage, border/hybrid knowledge, racial power movements (Black, Chican@...), the undercommons, and emergent intellectual collectives (critical ethnic studies; afro-pessimism; crunk feminist, Palestinian, settler colonial?)
